Patient Note:
A 57-year-old man with a history of hypertension and right hip fracture called emergency medical services and complained of severe leg pain. When the emergency medical services team arrived on scene, the patient was found down on the floor with right leg weakness; he was confused and aphasic. No fumes or smoke was evident. Due to altered mental status, he was intubated and was subsequently transferred to our medical facility. Six hours after the incident, the patient was more alert and oriented and his leg pain had subsided. Details of smoking history could not be obtained due to the intubation. On physical examination, temperature was 35.8°C, heart rate 107 bpm, blood pressure 137/94 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 14 breaths/minute. He had regular heart rhythm, no murmur or pericardial rub. His abdomen was soft with active bowel sound. There were no symptoms and signs of limb ischemia on admission. He had no leg pain, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, paresthesia, or paralysis. Motor power was at least grade 4 in all 4 extremities. His dorsalis pedis pulse was 2+ bilaterally. Initial investigations at our medical facility showed white blood cell 11400/µL, neutrophils 89%, hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL, hematocrit 38.6%, platelet 159000/µL, blood urea nitrogen 29 mg/dL, creatinine 2.0 mg/dL, sodium 142 mEq/L, potassium 3.9 mEq/L, chloride 102 mEq/L, bicarbonate 19 mEq/L, lactic acid 4.25 mmol/L, troponin T 0.1 ng/mL, and negative for acetone. Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and no ST-T change. The liver function test demonstrated aspartate aminotransferase 1697 IU/L, alanine aminotransferase 1263 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase 138 IU/L, total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL, total protein 6.2 gm/dL, and albumin 3.5 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed white blood cell 5 to 10/high-power field, red blood cell 0 to 3/high-power field, moderate blood but negative for urine myoglobin. Coagulogram showed prothrombin time 17.5 seconds, partial thromboplastin time 25.8 seconds, and international normalized ratio 1.59. Calculated fractional excretion of sodium and urea were 2.11% and 43.67%, respectively, consistent with acute tubular necrosis. The viral hepatitis panel was negative except for a positive AntiHBc IgG antibody. Arterial blood gas analysis on admission depicted pH 7.319, PO2 130.3 mm Hg, PCO2 40.8 mm Hg, HCO3 20.5 mEq/L, and Sao2 100%, carboxyhemoglobin 0.2%, and methemoglobin 0.1% while on assist-control mode of mechanical ventilation with Fio2 100%. Computed tomography of head was performed and showed chronic right basal ganglion infarct. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed and showed severely depressed left ventricular function with ejection fraction of less than 20%, grade II/IV diastolic dysfunction with mild TR, mild MR, and mild PR. Akinesis of the septal wall and hypokinesis of the anterolateral wall were present. Moreover, computed tomography of abdomen, pelvis, and chest without contrast revealed right lower lung consolidation with small right pleural effusion, moderately bilateral nonspecific perinephric fat stranding, submucosal fatty infiltration, and mild wall thickening of the descending colon down to the rectum. Subtle perirectal fat stranding was also visualized. Initially, he was treated with empiric antibiotics for possible pneumonia with severe sepsis with piperacillin-tazobactam, levofloxacin, and vancomycin. Aspirin and full-dose enoxaparin were started to cover possible acute coronary syndrome. Surgery was consulted due to a concern of bowel ischemia. Proctoscopy was done and showed normal pink rectal mucosa without blood in the vault. Because the patient was hemodynamically stable, had no abdominal pain, and lactic acid level had returned to normal, the surgery service recommended continued fluid replacement for volume expansion.
His lactate levels decreased spontaneously from 15 mmol/L to 3.39, 2.52, and 1.28 mmol/L at 0, 10, 14, and 33 hours, respectively, after his initial symptoms, along with an improvement of arterial pH and anion gap (). After 24 hours of admission, he improved dramatically and was extubated on day 2 of admission. Five hours after extubation (42 hours after admission), he started to have left leg pain. His left leg turned bluish and became paler with prominent livedo reticularis throughout his left leg (). Therefore, a heparin drip was initiated promptly and vascular surgery was consulted. Soon after that, the patient developed sudden cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity. He had return of spontaneous circulation after 15 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation. At that moment, his lactate level rebounded to 8.13 mmol/L. To rule out acute aortic dissection and acute massive pulmonary embolism as well as acute left limb gangrene from embolism, computed tomography of pulmonary artery with contrast and computed tomography angiogram of aorta were performed. He had no pulmonary emboli or abdominal aortic dissection. He did have high-grade stenosis of the infrarenal abdominal aorta just above the bifurcation, near total occlusion of the right common iliac artery, severe luminal narrowing of the left common iliac artery, bilateral external iliac arteries, and bilateral common femoral arteries by calcified and noncalcified plaques ( and ). Emergent revascularization was planned but the patient developed pulseless electrical activity/asystole again and passed away.

Patient Note: Patient has taken 7.01 mg of Dexamethasone IV.
Question: Based on the patient's dose of Dexamethasone IV, what is the equivalent dosage in mg of Hydrocortisone PO?
Ground Truth Explanation:
The Steroid Conversions providing equivalent doses for various corticosteroids are listed below:
1. Betamethasone: Route = IV, Equivalent Dose = 0.75 mg
2. Cortisone: Route = PO, Equivalent Dose = 25 mg
3. Dexamethasone (Decadron): Route = IV or PO, Equivalent Dose = 0.75 mg
4. Hydrocortisone: Route = IV or PO, Equivalent Dose = 20 mg
5. MethylPrednisoLONE: Route = IV or PO, Equivalent Dose = 4 mg
6. PrednisoLONE: Route = PO, Equivalent Dose = 5 mg
7. PredniSONE: Route = PO, Equivalent Dose = 5 mg
8. Triamcinolone: Route = IV, Equivalent Dose = 4 mg 
The mass of Dexamethasone IV is 7.01 mg. 
To convert from the Dexamethasone IV to Hydrocortisone PO, multiply by the conversion factor, 26.67 mg Hydrocortisone PO/Dexamethasone IV, giving us 7.01 mg Dexamethasone IV * 26.67 mg Hydrocortisone PO/mg Dexamethasone IV = 186.9567 mg Hydrocortisone PO. 7.01 mg of Dexamethasone IV is equal to 186.9567 mg of Hydrocortisone PO.

Patient Note: A 72-year-old man was seen in the cardiology office after being referred by his primary clinician for reassessment of anticoagulation in the setting of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation that was first documented five years ago during an emergency department visit for palpitations. He reports that his heart rhythm symptoms have been well controlled on metoprolol succinate 75 mg daily, and he has remained in sinus rhythm since a direct-current cardioversion performed six months earlier, but because of a recent episode of self-limited macroscopic hematuria his primary clinician requested a comprehensive review of factors that could influence bleeding risk. Today he describes no chest pain, dyspnea, focal neurologic complaints, or syncope. His blood pressure in the clinic, measured manually after five minutes of seated rest, is 168/92 mm Hg; he states that home readings are usually “in the 150s” despite adherence to lisinopril 40 mg and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. He has stage 3b chronic kidney disease attributed to hypertensive nephrosclerosis; baseline serum creatinine has fluctuated between 2.1 and 2.6 mg/dL over the past year, with the most recent value from last week at 2.4 mg/dL (eGFR approximately 28 mL/min/1.73 m²). He denies ever having been told of cirrhosis, viral hepatitis, or alcohol-related liver injury, and last month’s comprehensive metabolic panel showed AST 28 U/L, ALT 31 U/L, total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL, and normal albumin. There is no personal history of ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, transient ischemic attack, or intracranial hemorrhage, and he has never experienced retinal or spinal cord ischemic events. He underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with a drug-eluting stent in the mid-left anterior descending artery four years ago and has remained on aspirin 81 mg daily since that time; he takes naproxen 220 mg up to twice daily for lumbar osteoarthritis flare-ups, most recently two days ago after mowing his lawn. His other daily medications include warfarin (most recent INR 2.3), rosuvastatin 10 mg, and omeprazole 20 mg. He states he drinks two glasses of red wine on Friday and Saturday evenings, totalling 4 drinks per week, and otherwise denies liquor or beer consumption. He has never smoked cigarettes and quit chewing tobacco three decades ago. Family history is notable for a father who died of myocardial infarction at age 62 and a mother with age-related macular degeneration; no first-degree relatives have bleeding disorders. Review of systems is negative for melena, hematemesis, easy bruising, gingival bleeding, epistaxis, or abdominal tenderness. On examination he is alert and oriented, BMI 29 kg/m², pulse 68 bpm regular, respirations 16/min, and afebrile. Cardiovascular exam reveals normal S1 and S2 without murmurs or gallops; carotid upstrokes are brisk without bruits. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdomen is soft and non-tender with no hepatosplenomegaly, and there is no ascites. Extremities show no edema or petechiae; radial and dorsalis pedis pulses are intact. Neurologic exam is nonfocal with normal strength, sensation, and coordination. Laboratory data available from this morning include hemoglobin 12.8 g/dL, hematocrit 39 %, platelets 210 × 10⁹/L, BUN 48 mg/dL, sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 4.3 mmol/L, and INR pending. Urinalysis confirms trace protein and 5–10 red blood cells per high-power field without casts. An electrocardiogram obtained today shows normal sinus rhythm at 67 bpm, PR interval 180 ms, QRS 96 ms, QTc 430 ms, and no acute ischemic changes. A recent transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55 %, mild concentric hypertrophy, and left atrial enlargement measuring 4.4 cm, with no valvular vegetations or thrombus. He wishes to continue living an active lifestyle that includes caring for his grandchildren, gardening, and walking the neighborhood three times weekly, and he asks specifically about the balance between reducing stroke risk and avoiding future bleeding episodes as his kidney function worsens.
Question: What is the patient's HAS-BLED score? You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Relevant Entities: {'Liver disease criteria for the HAS-BLED rule': False, 'Renal disease criteria for the HAS-BLED rule': True, 'Hypertension': True, 'Stroke': False, 'Medication usage predisposing to bleeding': True, 'age': [72, 'years'], 'Number of Alcoholic Drinks Per Week': 4, 'Prior major bleeding or predisposition to bleeding': True, 'Labile international normalized ratio': False}
Ground Truth Explanation:
The criteria for the HAS-BLED score are listed below below:

He does not smoke and states that he consumes 0 alcoholic drinks per week, having abstained completely since his early seventies after the passing of his spouse. Patient Note: A 44-year-old Bangladeshi male was admitted to Hamad General Hospital on 31 December 2004 with progressive shortness of breath, fever, and productive cough with yellowish sputum of four days duration. His past history was remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), secondary polycythemia, pulmonary hypertension, and old pulmonary tuberculosis. He was maintained on salbutamol inhaler, fluticasone, and salmetrol discus inhaler, theophylline and home oxygen therapy. He denied receiving systemic corticosteroids in the preceding year. He was an ex-smoker and alcohol drinker. Physical examination on admission revealed an ill looking, dyspneic patient with a temperature 38.4°C, blood pressure 135/90 mm Hg, pulse rate 160/minute, and respiratory rate 36/minute. Chest examination revealed expiratory wheezes and bilateral basal crepitations. Otherwise, physical examination was unremarkable. Laboratory investigations revealed hemoglobin 13 mg/dL, white blood cell count (WBC) 14.6×109 /L (neutrophils 82%, lymphocytes 10%), platelets 25×109 /L, glucose 11.4 mmol/L, creatinine 135 mmol/L, sodium 129 mmol/L, potassium 3.8 mmol/L. Arterial blood gases revealed pH 7.19, PCO2 74.8 mm Hg, PO2 96 mm Hg. Chest radiograph showed no lung infiltrates. Sputum culture grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, sensitive to cefipime and ciprofloxacin; however, it was thought to represent colonization. A diagnosis of COPD with acute exacerbation was made, for which he was given intravenous ceftriaxone 2 gm once daily, azithromycin 500 mg once daily, methylprednisolone 40 mg three times daily, and salbutamol and ipratropium bromide nebulizers. He made a gradual improvement, and after seven days he was shifted to oral prednisolone 40 mg once daily and oral amoxicillin/clavulanic acid to complete two weeks of antibiotics. Prednisolone was given for a total of 13 days. Three weeks after admission he developed hemoptysis, chest tightness, and worsening cough. Sputum culture grew P aeruginosa for which he was given intravenous cefepime and ciprofloxacin. Sputum smear for acid fast bacilli (AFB) was negative. Because of worsening respiratory status and a chest radiograph showing an infiltrate involving the whole left lung and part of the right lung, bronchoscopy was performed on 27 January 2005. No endobronchial lesion was found. Antituberculous drugs in the form of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol were started. Bronchioalveolar lavage and bronchial wash were negative for AFB but bacterial culture grew P aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, and Klebisella pneumoniae. Cytologic examination of the bronchial wash and lavage revealed bronchial epithelial cells, few squamous cells in the background of numerous S stercoralis worms () and bacteria with inflammatory cells and blood. Transbronchial biopsy showed only intraalveolar hemorrhage with anthracotic pigments, but was negative for granuloma, viral inclusions, or malignancy. He was treated with oral ivermectin 12mg once daily. Two days later he complained of vomiting, lower abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and constipation. Physical examination revealed abdominal distention, lower abdominal tenderness, and sluggish bowel sounds. A plain radiograph of the abdomen revealed distended bowel loops but no air fluid levels. Lapratomy was done. The findings at surgery were a dilated jejunum and ileum filled with stool. Microscopic examination of the resected part of the ileum bowel revealed acute inflammation, mucosal hemorrhage, and focal ulceration with abundant S stercoralis larvae (Figures and ). Postoperatively, he was mechanically ventilated. His postoperative course was complicated by hypotension and multiorgan failure and he expired after two days.
Question: What is the patient's corrected sodium concentration for hyperglycemia in terms of mEq/L? Use the sodium correction equation based on the one derived in Hillier, 1999. You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Ground Truth Explanation:
The formula for Sodium Correction for Hyperglycemia based on Hiller, 1999 is Measured sodium + 0.024 * (Serum glucose - 100), where Measured Sodium is the sodium concentration in mEq/L and the Serum glucose is the concentration of glucose in mg/dL.
The concentration of sodium is 129.0 mmol/L. We need to convert the concentration to mEq/L. Let's first convert the mass of sodium from mmol to mEq. The mass of sodium is 129.0 mmol. The compound, sodium, has a valence of 1, and so multiply the valence by the value of mmol to get, 129.0 mmol * 1 mEq/mmol = 129.0 mEq sodium. The volume units is L so no volume conversion is needed. Hence, the concentration value of 129.0 mmol sodium/L converts to 129.0 mEq sodium/L. 
The concentration of glucose is 11.4 mmol/L. We need to convert the concentration to mg/dL. Let's first convert the mass of glucose from mmol to mg. The mass of glucose is 11.4 mmol. To convert 11.4 mmol of glucose to mol, multiply by the conversion factor 0.001, giving us 11.4 mmol glucose * 0.001 mol/mmol = 0.0114 mol glucose. To convert from mol glucose to grams, multiply by the molar mass 180.16 g/mol, which will give 0.0114 mol glucose * 180.16 g/mol = 2.05382 g glucose. To convert 2.05382 g of glucose to mg, multiply by the conversion factor 1000.0, giving us 2.05382 g glucose * 1000.0 mg/g = 2053.82 mg glucose. The current volume unit is L and the target volume unit is dL. The conversion factor is 10.0 dL for every unit of L. Our next step will be to divide the mass by the volume conversion factor of 10.0 to get the final concentration in terms of mg/dL. This will result to 2053.82 mg glucose/10.0 dL = 205.382 mg glucose/dL. The concentration value of 11.4 mmol glucose/L converts to 205.382 mg glucose/dL. 
Plugging in these values into the formula gives us 129.0 mEq/L + 0.024 * (205.382 - 100) = 131.52917 mEq/L.
Hence, the patient's corrected concentration of sodium is 131.52917 mEq/L.

Patient Note:
A 57-year-old man was admitted to the ED with complaints of syncope and weakness. We noticed that in his medical history, leeches were applied to treat the diabetic wounds on his feet two hours before he attended our clinic. After this, the leeches spontaneously detached but he observed bleeding from his bites and bleeding did not stop in spite of compression with tight bandages. A review of the patient’s past medical history revealed hypertension, diabetes mellitus, diabetic foot, ischemic heart disease and coronary artery bypass surgery.
Vital signs were as follows; fever: 36.6°C, blood pressure: 85/50 mmHg, heart rate: 112/min and respiratory rate: 28/min. Physical examination revealed tenderness in the whole abdomen. Ampulla was empty with rectal examination. There was an ulcerative lesion with size 5x3 cm on the site of the amputated first toe. Additionally, there were multiple bites due to leech therapy on both feet (Figure ).
Laboratory tests indicated the following: hemoglobin: 7.6 g/dL, white blood cells: 9370/mm3, platelets: 147000/mL, blood urea nitrogen: 29.1 mg/dL, creatinine: 1.98 mg/dL, glucose: 527 mg/dL, Na: 127 mmol/L, K: 6 mmol/L, CL: 94.5 mmol/L, C-reactive protein: 1.27 mg/dL and other routine blood tests and coagulation functions were all normal. Blood gas analysis revealed pH: 7.26, pO2: 86 mmHg, and bicarbonate: 20.2 mmol/L. Abdominal ultrasonography (USG) showed gas in the intrahepatic biliary ducts. No obstructive pathology was found to mesenteric blood flow on Doppler USG. CT without intravenous contrast was performed because of abnormal renal function tests. CT revealed gas near the stomach, among colon segments (pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis, PSI) and intrahepatic biliary ducts in central and left hepatic lobe (hepatic portal venous gas, HPVG) (Figure , Figure , respectively).
The patient was referred to another hospital that had an intensive care unit and started conservative treatment with antibiotics and intravenous fluid. Twelve hours after treatment, his general condition did not improve and signs of diffused peritonitis were observed on abdominal examination. The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy. Necrosis was found in the terminal ileum and the entire colon during laparotomy. Doppler USG detected low flow in the vessels supplying these necrotic segments. However, resection was decided due to necrosis of these segments. These necrotic intestinal segments were resected and an end-ileostomy was performed. He had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 17th postoperative day.

Patient Note:
A 47-year-old man visited the emergency room because of decreased mentality. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus (DM), but had not received regular treatment. His blood pressure was 60/30 mm Hg and body temperature was 38.5℃. Laboratory data showed white blood cell of 13.150×109/L, with a differential count of 90.7% neutrophils and 8.5% lymphocytes, hemoglobin of 14.3 g/dL, platelet count of 507×109/L, glucose levels of 443 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen of 52.5 mg/dL, serum creatinine concentrations of 1.9 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase of 69 IU/L, alanine transaminase of 38 IU/L, sodium of 125.7 mmol/L, potassium of 5.4 mmol/L, C-reactive protein (CRP) levels of 19.42 mg/dL, ketone bodies in the blood 3 positive and HbA1c of 18.20%. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.032, pCO2 of 21.8 mm Hg, pO2 of 83.3 mm Hg, and HCO3 of 5.8 mmol/L. Chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) scans showed multiple consolidation and ground glass opacities in both lung fields (). The patient was initially diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis as a result of severe pneumonia. An immediate hydration and insulin therapy were started, and dose-adjusted piperacillin and tazobactam sodium were also administered for pneumonia. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for mechanical ventilator therapy. The ketoacidosis had improved with hydration and insulin therapy, but on the second day of hospitalization, diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema developed and continuous renal replacement therapy was started. Klebsiella pneumonia was identified in sputum cultures. After 8 days of treatment, the lung lesions had regressed (). The patient was finally moved to the general ward. However, on the 5th day in the general ward, he started complaining of vague abdominal pain. His pain had aggravated with severe tenderness. An erect abdominal X-ray showed gaseous distention of small bowel loops with suspicious stepladder sign, suggesting mechanical obstruction (). Subsequent abdominal CT suggested multiple perforation of the transverse colon with panperitonitis ().
An emergency laparotomy was performed. Necrotic intestines were observed from the distal ascending colon to the proximal transverse colon. Necrotic portions were resected and the Periodic Acid Schiff and Grocott's methenamine silver staining of the resected specimen showed septated fungal hyphae with acute angle branching, suggesting aspergillus species (). The patient was finally diagnosed with colonic IA. Intravenous liposomal amphotericin-B (3 mg/kg/day) was additionally administered for 35 days. He was discharged with oral voriconazole to treat his reported remaining, abdominal discomfort and mildly elevated CRP levels. Voriconazole was discontinued at a follow-up visit to the outpatient department 2 weeks after discharge when his abdominal discomfort had relieved and CRP levels normalized.

Patient Note:
A 66-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension, alcohol use, and asthma presented with facial swelling. He was discharged two months prior for a similar event related to lisinopril. On initial presentation, the patient's vitals were significant for heart rate of 104 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99% with a non-rebreather mask at 15 liters. Physical exam was significant for moderate to severe respiratory distress, inspiratory stridor, and subcostal and intercostal retractions. Lungs were clear to auscultation. The patient was otherwise alert and oriented. Arterial blood gas showed pH 7.447, pCO2 39, pO2 197, and HCO3 27 on 60% FiO2. His initial metabolic panel was significant for sodium 104 mmol/L, potassium 2.6 mmol/L, chloride 66 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 5 mg/dL (baseline 20 mg/dL), and creatinine 0.6 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL). Glucose was 165 mg/dL. Magnesium and phosphorus were 1.1 and 2.1 mg/dL, respectively. Serum uric acid was low at 2.7 mg/dL. Complete blood count showed no leukocytosis or anemia. Urinalysis had a specific gravity of 1.010, moderate blood, and 15-29 red blood cells. Urine electrolytes were notable for a sodium of 48 mmol/L and osmolality of 217 mOsm/kg. Serum osmolality was 215 mOsm/kg. Urine and serum toxicology were negative for any substances. Alcohol level was negative.
Due to concern for airway protection, the patient was intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit. Initial chest x-ray held concern for infectious process, but antibiotics were stopped after infectious workup was negative. The patient was given two units of fresh-frozen plasma, famotidine, and Benadryl, and started on methylprednisolone 60 mg every six hours for angioedema. Lisinopril was held at this time. For his hyponatremia, the patient's labs were suspicious for syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and a one-liter fluid restriction was initiated with nephrology consult. Thyroid and adrenal workup to rule out other causes of SIADH was unremarkable. A CT chest scan was done to evaluate for malignancy as a cause of SIADH, but did not demonstrate overt suspicious lung pathology (Figure ). The patient's hyponatremia appropriately corrected over the course of one week and was 130 mmol/L upon discharge. Lisinopril was discontinued and marked as an allergy for the patient. On follow-up approximately nine months later, the patient's sodium had corrected and remained within normal limits.

Patient Note:
A 67-year-old male with a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, non-insulin–dependent diabetes mellitus, and hypertension presented with progressively worsening dyspnea and cough of three weeks duration. Two months prior to presentation, the patient had undergone cardiac resynchronization therapy-defibrillator (CRT-D) placement for nonischemic cardiomyopathy and left bundle branch block with a left ventricular ejection fraction of less than 35%. No operative complications were reported.
Vital signs were within normal limits (pulse: 84 beats per minute; blood pressure: 132/68 mmHg; temperature: 36.1°C; respiratory rate: 18; oxygen saturation: 94% on room air). Physical examination was significant only for bibasilar rales; no pericardial friction rub or elevated jugular venous pressure were appreciated, and there were no clinical signs or symptoms concerning for tamponade. Laboratory studies demonstrated hyponatremia (sodium: 123 mEq/L), hyperglycemia (glucose: 260 mg/dL), and normocytic anemia (hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume: 86.7 fL). N-terminal pro b-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) was elevated to 239 pg/mL, which was near the patient's baseline. Serum potassium, bicarbonate, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine were within normal limits. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed an atrial-paced ventricular rhythm consistent with prior pacemaker placement. Two-view chest radiography revealed an enlarged cardiac silhouette, minimal bibasilar atelectasis, and appropriate placement of the pacemaker leads ().
The patient was started on a fluid restriction of 1500 milliliters per day for hyponatremia and suspected heart failure exacerbation. However, subsequent laboratory studies showed significant worsening of the hyponatremia; by the second hospital day, the patient's serum sodium had decreased from 123 to 119 mEq/L (corrected for hyperglycemia: 123 mEq/L). Further investigation revealed serum blood urea nitrogen of 12 mg/dl, serum glucose of 264 mg/dl, calculated serum osmolality of 256 mOsm/kg, urine osmolality of 310 mOsm/kg H2O, and urine sodium of 42 mEq/L. Hypothyroidism was ruled out with a thyroid-stimulating hormone of 2.340 μIU/mL.
An echocardiogram demonstrated a large circumferential pericardial effusion with right atrial collapse (). Left ventricular ejection fraction was estimated at 55% with normal diastolic function. Diastolic right ventricular collapse was absent. Echocardiographic features were consistent with early signs of cardiac tamponade. However, there were no clinical signs of tamponade and vital signs remained within normal limits.
An urgent pericardiocentesis was performed with removal of approximately 1200 milliliters of sanguineous fluid. A follow-up echocardiogram was obtained one day after the procedure and demonstrated complete resolution of the effusion (). Serum electrolytes were monitored and showed a gradual improvement of the hyponatremia; serum sodium had increased from 120 to 123 mEq/L on the first postoperative day and to 131 mEq within 36 hours of the procedure (). Calculated serum osmolality also increased to 278 mOsm/kg. Analysis of the pericardial fluid was negative for malignant cells and pathogens. Our patient's pericardial effusion was presumed to be secondary to his previous CRT-D placement. The patient was discharged home in stable condition on the third postoperative day. Outpatient follow-up four weeks later showed no recurrence of the pericardial effusion.

The concentration of sodium is 123.0 mEq/L. 
The concentration of glucose is 260.0 mg/dL. 
Plugging in these values into the formula gives us 123.0 mEq/L + 0.024 * (260.0 - 100) = 126.84 mEq/L.
Hence, the patient's corrected concentration of sodium is 126.84 mEq/L.

Patient Note:
A 33-year-old male presented to our center with chief complaints of profuse per rectal bleed mixed with stool for three days that was associated with easy fatigability for one week prior to the initial presentation. He also had one episode of black tarry stool. However, he had no complaints of blood in vomit, purpuric rashes, or petechiae. He also had no hematuria, weight loss, night sweats, evening rise of temperature or loss of appetite, cough, chest pain, dyspnea, palpitation, limb edema, loose stools, jaundice, and abdominal distension. Bleeding was absent from other orifices. He had no history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cardiac diseases, and pulmonary tuberculosis in the past. He consumed 80 grams of alcohol per day for 15 years, but he did not smoke.
On examination, he was ill looking, conscious, and was well oriented to time place and person. He had pallor and was dehydrated. However, he had no icterus, clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. His pulse rate was 110 beats/minute, blood pressure was 80/60 mm of Hg, body temperature was 98°F (36.6°C), respiratory rate was 19 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation was 95% in room air. The digital rectal examination showed fresh blood over the examining finger and otherwise normal findings. Abdominal and cardiac examination was normal.
Laboratory investigations showed hemoglobin 10.8 g/dl and hematocrit 31.6%. The total leukocyte count was 11510/mm3, neutrophils were 78%, and platelet count was 291000/mm3. The prothrombin time was 14 seconds, and the International normalized ratio was 1.08. The albumin level in the blood was 2.4 gm/dl, and total protein was 6.1 gm/dl, total and direct bilirubin were 0.7 and 0.1 mg/dl in the blood. Alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase level was 97 U/L and 114 U/L, respectively. HbA1C level in the blood was 7.2. The level of blood urea nitrogen (33 mg/dl), creatinine (1.1 mg/dl), sodium (132 mEq/l), and potassium (3.6 mEq/l) were within normal range. Traces of sugar and albumin (++) were present in the urine examination. The fecal occult blood was found in the stool. Mycobacterium tuberculosis was not detected in sputum in the acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stain.
The chest X-ray was normal. Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen and pelvis and upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed normal findings. A Computed Tomography (CT) scan of chest and abdomen showed asymmetric circumferential thickening in the ileocaecal region with lobulated thickened caecum, soft-tissue stranding and necrotic mesenteric lymphadenopathy, and indeterminate lobule in the lung (). Colonoscopy showed multiple transverse ulcers with overlying exudates in terminal ileum and ascending and transverse colon. Histopathological examination of the ileum and colon showed patchy ulcers with exudates, granulation tissue, fibrosis, deep lymphoplasmocytic inflammation, and crypt regenerative changes with fibrinoid changes in scattered capillaries and venules and was inconclusive. However, gene XPERT was positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
He was diagnosed with ileocaecal tuberculosis. The hemoglobin level dropped to 6.1 g/dl after two days of admission, and he had an episode of weakness associated with profuse sweating and rigor. Fluid resuscitation followed by two pints of whole blood transfusion was performed. After that, his hemoglobin was increased to 10.2 mg/dl. He was managed with four antitubercular drugs and showed significant improvement. Following this, he was discharged on oral antitubercular medications (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine) after 10 days of admission. On follow-up after two weeks, he was responding well to antitubercular medications with improved symptoms, i.e., no per rectal bleeding, and his liver function test was within the normal range.
Question: What is the patient's Glasgow-Blatchford Bleeding score? You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Relevant Entities: {'Heart Rate or Pulse': [110, 'beats per minute'], 'Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)': [33, 'mg/dL'], 'sex': 'Male', 'Hemoglobin': [10.8, 'g/dL'], 'Melena present': True, 'Systolic Blood Pressure': [80, 'mm Hg'], 'Recent syncope': False, 'Cardiac failure present': False}
Ground Truth Explanation:
The criteria for the Glasgow-Blatchford Score are listed below:

1. BUN (mg/dL): <18.2 = 0 points, 18.2-22.3 = +2 points, 22.4-28 = +3 points, 28-70 = +4 points, >70 = +6 points
2. Hemoglobin (g/dL) for men: >=13 = 0 points, <=12-13 = +1 point, <=10-12 = +3 points, <10 = +6 points
3. Hemoglobin (g/dL) for women: >=12 = 0 points, <=10-12 = +1 point, <10 = +6 points
4. Systolic blood pressure (mm Hg): ≥110 = 0 points, 100-109 = +1 point, 90-99 = +2 points, <90 = +3 points
5. Pulse ≥100 (per minute): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
6. Melena present: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
7. Presentation with syncope: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
8. Liver disease history: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
9. Cardiac failure present: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point

The total Glasgow-Blatchford Score is calculated by summing the points for each criterion.
The current glasgow bleeding score is 0. The patient's gender is Male.
The concentration of hemoglobin is 10.8 g/dL. Because the patient is a male and his hemoglobin concentration is greater than or equal to 10 g/dL, but less than 12 g/dL, we add three points, making the current score 0 + 3 = 3.
The concentration of BUN is 33 mg/dL. The BUN concentration is between 28 and 70 mg/dL, and so we add four points, making the current score 3 + 4 = 7.
The patient's blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Because the patient's systolic blood pressure is less than 90 mm Hg, we increase the score by three points, making the current score 7 + 3 = 10.
The patient's heart rate is 110 beats per minute. Because the heart rate is greater or equal to than 100 beats per minute, we increase the score by one point, making the current score 10 + 1 = 11.
The patient has melena and so we add one point to the current total, making the current total 11 + 1 =  12.
The patient's status for recent syncope is reported to be absent for the patient, and so we do not add any points, keeping the current total at 12.
The patient's status for hepatic disease history is missing from the patient note and so we assume it is absent from the patient.
Hence, we do not add any points to the score, keeping it at 12.
The patient's status for cardiac failure is reported to be absent for the patient, and so we do not add any points, keeping the current total at 12.
The patient's Glasgow Bleeding Score is 12.

Patient Note:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening upper abdominal pain. She reports nausea and vomiting, and is unable to tolerate oral intake. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/85 mm Hg. Examination shows yellowish discoloration of her sclera. Her abdomen is tender in the right upper quadrant. There is no abdominal distention or organomegaly. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 432 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 196 U/L
Aspartate transaminase 207 U/L
Bilirubin
Total 3.8 mg/dL
Direct 2.7 mg/dL
Lipase 82 U/L (N = 14–280)
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows dilated intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and multiple hyperechoic spheres within the gallbladder. The pancreas is not well visualized. Intravenous fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole is begun. Twelve hours later, the patient appears acutely ill and is not oriented to time. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 112/82 mm Hg.

Patient Note:
A 91-year-old male with hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a longstanding history of CD, noncompliant with a gluten-free diet, presented to the ED for evaluation of intermittent upper abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds over a period of two months. His vital signs were initially normal, however, after an episode of hematemesis followed by hematochezia, he became hypotensive to 80/60 mmHg and tachycardic to 100 beats/min. Physical examination was notable for pale conjunctiva and tenderness to palpation in the upper abdomen. Laboratory evaluation revealed a white blood cell count of 13.2 x 103/uL (reference (R): 4.5-11.0 x 103/uL), hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL (R: 12-17 g/dL), blood urea nitrogen of 34 mg/dL (R: 5-25 mg/dL), and creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL (R: 0.6-1.8 mg/dL). CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated a 6.8 cm dilated proximal jejunum (Figure ).
The patient was resuscitated with four units of packed red blood cells and two liters of normal saline. Intravenous pantoprazole was administered. Surgery was consulted and a nasogastric tube was placed for gastric decompression. Small bowel enteroscopy discovered two nonbleeding superficial clean-based ulcers in the duodenum and an ulcerated jejunal mass, which appeared to be the source of bleeding. Biopsies from the mass showed an invasive, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Subsequently, exploratory laparotomy revealed additional masses in the ileum and transverse colon suspicious for malignancy; thus, partial small bowel and partial colonic resection with end colostomy and Hartmann’s pouch were performed. The mass in the jejunum measured 1.7 cm x 1 cm x 0.2 cm. Pathologic evaluation revealed invasive, poorly differentiated carcinoma with gland formation only in the lesion resected from jejunum (Figure ). Cytokeratin was immunoreactive (Figure ). CK7, CK20, TTF-1, LCA, CD56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin stains were negative. Regional resected lymph nodes and other resected lesions were devoid from cancer. The American Joint Committee of Cancer (AJCC) stage was pT2N0. The patient’s post-operative course was uncomplicated, and he was discharged with outpatient oncology follow up. On follow up visit four weeks after surgery, the patient was recovering well and without any complaints. He was offered chemotherapy, but declined any treatment.

Patient Note: A 34-year-old Caucasian female with prior history of hypertension was admitted at the Department of Ophthalmology of our hospital for bilateral red eye. She had no previous ocular trauma or surgery, and no other complaints. Ophthalmological examination showed bilateral diffuse anterior scleritis. Visual acuity was preserved. On admission, blood pressure was of 150/100 mmHg, and heart rate was of 72 beats per minute. Ear, nose and mouth examination was normal, and cardiac, pulmonary, abdominal, neurological and lower limbs examination also revealed no changes. Neither joint tenderness or effusion nor rash, nor peripheral lymphadenopathies were detected. There was no genital ulceration. The laboratory disclosed normal renal function (creatinaemia 1.18 mg/dL; blood urea nitrogen 40 mg/dL) and normal haemoglobin (12.9 g/dL). Urinalysis featured microscopic haematuria (150 erythrocytes/microlitre) and proteinuria of 3.59 g/day. Serum albumin was 3.4 g/dL, and there was evidence of high total cholesterol level (total cholesterol, 254 mg/dL). Serum protein electrophoresis, serum protein immunoelectrophoresis, hepatic function tests, erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein were normal. Serology for lupus (antinuclear, anti-double strand deoxyribonucleic acid, anti-Smith, extractable nuclear and anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies) and vasculitis (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) as well as the search for cryoglobulins was negative. Rheumatoid factor was negative, and serum C3 and serum C4 were on the normal range. Serology for human immunodeficiency virus types 1 and 2, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, syphilis, and Lyme disease was also negative. Chest X-ray was normal. Renal ultrasound revealed normal-sized and normoechoic kidneys, normal differentiation, and no hydronephrosis. A kidney biopsy was performed, and revealed diffuse mesangial hypercellularity () and diffuse granular mesangial deposits of IgA (). According to these, the diagnosis of IgAN was established. She started oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day), lisinopril (20 mg/day), losartan (50 mg/day) and simvastatin (20 mg/day). Six months later, she was asymptomatic, and no other episodes of scleritis occurred. Ophthalmological examination was normal. Proteinuria decreased but still persisted in non-nephrotic range (2.3 g/24 h). Renal function still remains normal.

Patient Note: A 35-year-old male presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 3 days. There was no history of fever or jaundice in the past. He was chronic alcoholic; consuming 400–500 mL country liquor daily for the past 10 years. On examination, he was afebrile with a pulse rate of 124/min and blood pressure of 110/80 mmHg. He had pallor, icterus, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. The first differential diagnosis was alcoholic hepatitis and pancreatitis. Ryle's tube (RT) was inserted for gastric decompression. Initial management consisted of intravenous fluids, rabeprazole, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Investigations revealed the following: hemoglobin: 10 g/dl, white blood cell count 13,000/mm3, platelet count 210,000/mm3, serum bilirubin 6 mg/dl, direct bilirubin 4.2 mg/dl, aspartate aminotransferase 242 U/L, alanine aminotransferase 188 U/L, gamma-glutamyltransferase 121 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 52 IU/L, serum creatinine 1.2 mg/dl, blood urea nitrogen 30 mg/dl, serum amylase 189 U/L, serum lipase 490 U/L, and normal chest X-ray. Ultrasound (USG) abdomen showed hepatomegaly with increased echotexture and a bulky pancreas. CT scan abdomen showed diffuse enlargement of the pancreas with heterogeneous enhancement and shaggy contour, blurring of peripancreatic fat planes with fat stranding, thickening of fascial planes, and the presence of intraperitoneal fluid collections. While on supportive medical management, his hemoglobin dropped to 8 g/dl in the next 2 days. RT aspiration was clear. Upper gastrointestinal (UGI) endoscopy was performed to identify the bleed source. UGI endoscopy showed no varices and no peptic ulcer, but oozing of fresh blood was identified from the ampulla of Vater []. As hemoglobin was low on admission also, the patient must have GI bleeding since the onset of acute pancreatitis. Computed tomography (CT) angiography identified aneurysms at the distal end of the splenic artery []. Continuous bleed from ruptured splenic artery aneurysm resulted in hemorrhagic shock. The patient was resuscitated with multiple units of packed red cell transfusions. In view of deteriorating general condition of the patient and suspected infected peripancreatic collection, open surgery was planned. Distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy were performed for the ruptured splenic artery aneurysm. Pathological examination showed giant cell reaction surrounded by fibrosis nearby a polymorphonuclear infiltrate suggestive of acute inflammation in a setting of chronic pancreatitis. It also confirmed peripancreatic hematoma and splenic artery pseudoaneurysm communicating with the pancreatic duct consistent with hemosuccus pancreaticus (HP). Postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition after 2 weeks of surgery.

Patient Note: A 72-year-old male with leukemia was brought to the hospital for urgent evaluation after experiencing several days of progressive fatigue, mild shortness of breath, and lower abdominal discomfort. He appeared mildly flushed on arrival, with a body temperature of 37.5°C and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Due to the concerning nature of his presentation, he was rapidly admitted to the intensive care unit and underwent prompt assessment. His initial blood pressure measurements showed systolic readings at 120 mm Hg and diastolic readings around 64 mm Hg. Further examination revealed that his heartbeat was regular, averaging approximately 88 beats per minute. He denied any recent episodes of confusion or altered sensorium, and his neurological evaluation was consistent with a Glasgow Coma Score of 15 that reflected full alertness. His arterial blood gas analysis indicated a pH of 7.42, suggesting no major acid-base disturbance at this time, although there remained a heightened concern for potential clinical changes given his risk profile. The fraction of inspired oxygen he required on admission was around 45%, and his measured partial pressure of oxygen was approximately 72 mm Hg, reported in the context of his ongoing respiratory complaints. Laboratory studies performed shortly after arrival showed a sodium concentration of 136 mEq/L and a potassium concentration of 4.3 mEq/L, which were within acceptable limits. However, his serum creatinine level was elevated at 1.8 mg/dL, necessitating careful monitoring of his renal function. Despite this elevated level, there was no immediate concern for acute kidney injury on top of this finding, and he did not manifest signs of significant fluid overload or severe acid-base derangements. His hematocrit was measured at 34%, which was slightly reduced but not acutely critical, and his white blood cell count reached around 12,800 per cubic millimeter, raising the possibility of an infectious or inflammatory process given his background and presenting symptoms. He maintained full orientation according to clinical observation, with preserved verbal and motor responses consistent with a normal level of alertness. Owing to the acuity of his presentation, he underwent an emergent exploratory procedure for a suspected intra-abdominal source of infection or complication, and he was closely observed in the postoperative and critical care setting because of his predisposition to severe infections. Prior medical history included issues that compromise his overall immune defense, so heightened surveillance and aggressive prophylactic measures were implemented. Throughout the initial hours after intervention, he received supportive care while monitoring his respiratory parameters and hemodynamic stability. Additional imaging was obtained to clarify the etiology of his symptoms, and cultures were taken to identify any possible pathogens. Discussion among the care team emphasized vigilance for potential complications, including careful fluid balance and reassessment of his renal parameters. As the hours progressed, he remained hemodynamically stable with no new signs of deteriorating consciousness, and his temperature remained near baseline without further fever spikes. Plans for ongoing management included tailored antimicrobial therapy once specific organisms were identified, potential adjustment of his oxygen requirements if his lung function changed, and continued evaluation of his creatinine level to ensure there was no worsening of renal status. Throughout his stay, detailed monitoring of his laboratory values and clinical status was prioritized, given his significant risk factors and the emergent nature of his presentation.

7. Oxygenation (use PaO₂ if FiO₂ < 50%, otherwise use A-a gradient): A-a gradient > 499 = +4 points, A-a gradient 350-499 = +3 points, A-a gradient 200-349 = +2 points, A-a gradient < 200 (if FiO₂ ≥ 50%) or PaO₂ > 70 (if FiO₂ < 50%) = 0 points, PaO₂ 61-70 = +1 point, PaO₂ 55-60 = +3 points, PaO₂ < 55 = +4 points.

9. Serum sodium, mmol/L: ≥180 = +4 points, 160 to <180 = +3 points, 155 to <160 = +2 points, 150 to <155 = +1 point, 130 to <150 = 0 points, 120 to <130 = +2 points, 111 to <120 = +3 points, <111 = +4 points
10. Serum potassium, mmol/L: ≥7.0 = +4 points, 6.0 to <7.0 = +3 points, 5.5 to <6.0 = +1 point, 3.5 to <5.5 = 0 points, 3.0 to <3.5 = +1 point, 2.5 to <3.0 = +2 points, <2.5 = +4 points
11. Serum creatinine, mg/100 mL: ≥3.5 and ACUTE renal failure = +8 points, 2.0 to <3.5 and ACUTE renal failure = +6 points, ≥3.5 and CHRONIC renal failure = +4 points, 1.5 to <2.0 and ACUTE renal failure = +4 points, 2.0 to <3.5 and CHRONIC renal failure = +3 points, 1.5 to <2.0 and CHRONIC renal failure = +2 points, 0.6 to <1.5 = 0 points, <0.6 = +2 points

14. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 1-15 points (use 15 - [GCS Score])

Patient Note: A 74-year-old male was brought to the intensive care unit with a high fever, respiratory difficulty, and marked lethargy that raised immediate concerns about a serious ongoing process. He had a known vulnerability regarding his body’s defense mechanisms, placing him at risk for severe complications, and he had recently undergone an operative intervention that had been arranged in advance rather than on short notice, arriving in the ICU in the immediate postoperative period. His Glasgow Coma Score was calculated at 4. His family reported that he had been progressively more tired and confused over the previous day, culminating in an acute decline prompting emergency transport. Vital sign measurements at presentation showed a high body temperature of 39.2 °C, correlating with his flushed skin and possible infectious or inflammatory process. His pulse was recorded at about 89 beats per minute, relatively stable but concerning in the context of the other findings, and his respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute, reflecting an increased workload of breathing. Measurement of arterial pressures yielded a systolic reading of 128 mm Hg and diastolic of 71 mm Hg. Though these blood pressure indices did not indicate frank shock, they demanded close monitoring given his precarious clinical state. Blood tests drawn immediately revealed a serum sodium of 147 mEq/L and potassium of 4.8 mEq/L, suggesting that some electrolytes were at the higher end of normal ranges and warranting repeated checks to detect any further derangements. Of greater concern was the markedly elevated creatinine level measured at 2.6 mg/dL; this indicated a deterioration of renal function in the absence of any documented longstanding kidney disease. His hematocrit was reduced to 29 %, potentially reflecting either chronic anemia or an acute drop that might impair oxygen-carrying capacity and limit the body’s physiologic reserves. Further laboratory data showed that his total white blood cell population was around 10,400 cells/mm³, a mild elevation that could signal an infectious process or another inflammatory trigger. His arterial blood sample exhibited a pH of 7.46, suggesting a mild shift toward alkalinity or a compensated state that could change quickly depending on ongoing metabolic or respiratory stresses. On arrival, he was placed on a markedly increased FiO2 at 80 %, well above half of the inhaled air, to maintain adequate oxygenation. Despite this high supplemental oxygen, his calculated alveolar–arterial oxygen gradient was markedly elevated at about 220 mm Hg, indicating a significant impairment in gas exchange. Clinically, he appeared tachypneic and demonstrated labored inhalations, with accessory muscle recruitment evident on inspection. He had no documented history of chronically reduced kidney function, and conversations with relatives indicated that he had not faced kidney-related admissions in the past, suggesting a new onset for his current renal issue. Given his severe mental status changes, the team worried about the risk of airway compromise or inability to guard the airway should his neurologic function worsen. At the same time, care had to be taken to evaluate potential causes of his elevated temperature, which ranged beyond typical low-grade readings. Because of the level of sedation required to keep him comfortable and safe for further investigations, the team recognized the urgency in ruling out primary infections and other acute problems, particularly in light of his inherent predisposition to complications from infectious agents or organ insults. Plans were considered for imaging studies to identify possible sources of infection, bleeding, or other triggers for abrupt decompensation, while also evaluating for potential complications related to his recent surgery rather than planning any new operative procedure at that time. By the time he underwent initial laboratory and clinical evaluations, he remained in a state of severely impaired consciousness, and his breathing dynamics signaled the possibility of impending respiratory compromise if interventions were delayed. The clinical picture suggested a complex interplay of high fever, acute renal derangement, and disordered mentation, all superimposed on a background of increased susceptibility to severe illness. Ongoing discussions among the critical care team centered on stabilizing him hemodynamically, preventing further organ dysfunction, and determining whether additional operative management would be necessary after his recent elective procedure or whether more extensive stabilization measures needed to precede any further intervention. His condition at the bedside underscored the delicate balance of supporting his circulation, protecting against the risk of worsening kidney injury, and identifying any treatable source of fever. Despite the absence of a known chronic kidney process, the elevated creatinine on arrival emphasized the need for meticulous oversight, including repeated checks of his urine output and the potential for renal imaging if indicated. Throughout this initial assessment, it was evident that further deterioration in vital parameters could precipitate significant danger for a patient with such weakened baseline defenses, reinforcing the necessity of prompt diagnostics and possible interventions.

Patient Note: A 70-year-old individual with a known vulnerability that compromises the body’s defenses was transferred to the intensive care unit from the emergency department following several days of general malaise, reduced appetite, and progressive confusion. A formal assessment revealed a Glasgow Coma Score of 5. The initial temperature measurement was 36.8°C, suggesting that fever was not contributing to the presentation at that point, and cardiovascular assessments showed a systolic pressure of 124 mm Hg coupled with a diastolic pressure of 69 mm Hg. The heart rate registered at approximately 84 beats per minute, reflecting a relatively stable rhythm, and the respiratory rate was 14 breaths per minute with unlabored breathing, indicating no overt signs of increased respiratory effort at that time. Laboratory values painted a picture of mild deviations, including a serum sodium level of 144 mEq/L and a serum potassium level of 4.6 mEq/L, both of which were within broadly acceptable limits. Some degree of renal insufficiency prompted concern, as the serum creatinine measured of 2.0 mg/dL, indicative of acute renal failure. Hematologic findings offered further insight, with the hematocrit close to 41% and a white blood cell count of 11,400 per cubic millimeter, hinting at a mild elevation suggestive of possible infection or inflammation. Additional investigation into the acid-base status showed an arterial pH of 7.43, implying near-normal balance in the absence of overt metabolic or respiratory derangements. By the time the arterial blood gas was analyzed, the individual was breathing under ambient conditions, so the fraction of inspired oxygen was only that found in room air at 21%. Despite the minimal external respiratory support, the arterial oxygen tension held steady at 75 mm Hg, which did not raise concern for significant gas-exchange impairment. Nonetheless, the patient’s dangerously decreased awareness level raised alarms, as the mental status evaluation suggested a pattern of profound disorientation and an inability to communicate consistently. This profound alteration was a striking feature, especially in a setting where defenses against infections or other stressors are suspected to be less robust than normal. Although the admission was prompted by concerns of rapid clinical decline in the context of immune vulnerability, there was no intention to undertake a procedure that involved opening a body cavity or relying on invasive operative strategies; rather, the approach at this juncture was to evaluate comprehensively for potential sources of deterioration, to stabilize organ function, and to ensure that any significant complications, whether infectious or inflammatory, were addressed immediately. Prior to this episode, the patient had not been known to have chronic dysfunction of the kidneys, and there were no records of frequent hemodialysis or an ongoing requirement for renal replacement therapies. Close neurological observation was carried out, considering the low responsiveness that placed the individual at a high risk for airway compromise and other complications unless carefully managed. Subsequent imaging studies, blood cultures, and specialist consultations were all under consideration as part of the initial workup. The decision to refrain from pursuing any invasive surgical route was based on the patient’s background, the lack of localizing signs that would point to a lesion needing operative intervention, and the immediate need to focus on controlling possible infection, ensuring stable hemodynamics, and improving the severely impaired level of consciousness. Throughout the assessment process, there was an emphasis on vigilant monitoring of vital signs, periodic reevaluation of the patient’s neuro status, and stringent hygienic measures to guard against hospital-acquired complications, especially given the compromised state of the immune system. All these findings reflected the patient’s baseline condition upon presentation, well before any targeted therapies or advanced interventions had been initiated, underscoring the importance of timely evaluation and ongoing supportive care for an individual whose physiologic reserves might be less capable of containing even minor insults without rapid deterioration.

Patient Note: A 77-year-old female arrived in the intensive care unit with a high fever and concerning changes in mental status. She had experienced a sudden onset of chills the previous evening, and by the time she was evaluated, her temperature had risen to 39.0 degrees Celsius. Blood pressure readings showed a systolic measurement of 115 mm Hg with a diastolic of 62 mm Hg. Although her pulse was not remarkably elevated at 92 beats per minute, she did exhibit some irregularities in her breathing pattern and was found to have a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Her oxygen requirements had increased significantly, with an inspired oxygen concentration of 55%, higher than one might expect in a standard clinical scenario. Laboratory tests revealed a markedly widened alveolar–arterial oxygen difference measured at 180 mm Hg, pointing to significant compromise in her respiratory function and prompting closer monitoring. Additional lab work showed normal serum sodium at 140 mEq/L and a potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L, suggesting that her electrolytes were relatively balanced save for a newly noted rise in her kidney-related markers. Specifically, her creatinine measured 2.2 mg/dL, signaling a recent decline in renal clearance that was not previously documented in her records and suggesting an abrupt change rather than a long-established abnormality. She also had a white blood cell count of 11,500 per cubic millimeter, indicating a probable inflammatory or infectious process. Hematocrit was measured at 37%, which was slightly lower than her personal baseline but not alarmingly so. When assessed for neurological function, she showed signs of confusion and a diminished capacity to follow commands, consistent with a GCS score of 11. This was a notable drop from her previously reported orientation level, as she had been described by her family as independently functioning with no significant cognitive deficits just days prior. Her arterial blood gas analysis indicated a pH of 7.35, which was on the lower side of normal but still within a tolerable range, obliging the clinical team to keep a close watch on her acid-base status to ensure it did not worsen over time. She had no clear history of conditions that severely compromise immune function, and based on her current presentation, there was no evidence that she was in a postoperative state. Despite her advanced age, she had not undergone any significant procedure in the recent past that might have influenced her immediate condition. The sudden nature of her renal issues, in the context of her fever and infection markers, raised concern for an acute process placing further strain on her kidneys. She did not mention any previous longstanding diagnosis of kidney disease, and her prior medical records lacked any indication of a chronic decline in renal function. At the time of initial ICU evaluation, her decreased alertness and the rise in markers of infection were the primary focus, with close attention to her respiratory status given her high oxygen requirement and significant oxygen gradient. The team planned to proceed with a thorough infectious workup, including blood cultures and imaging, while closely following her hemodynamic parameters, ensuring that any adjustments to supportive measures would be guided by her kidney function, mental status, and laboratory trends in the coming hours.

Patient Note: A 56-year-old male arrived at the intensive care setting after experiencing several days of progressive fatigue, occasional bouts of dizziness, and a noticeable rise in his body temperature by the time he became acutely unwell. On initial evaluation—before any interventions—he was found to have a moderately elevated heart rate at 99 beats per minute, and he was breathing at a notably rapid pace of 29 breaths per minute, suggesting increased respiratory effort likely related to both his febrile state and underlying physiological stress. In fact, his core temperature was measured at 38.5 °C, indicative of a fever that raised immediate concern for an infectious or inflammatory etiology. The blood pressure measurements revealed a systolic value of 126 mm Hg with a diastolic reading of 73 mm Hg. From a laboratory standpoint, he displayed a high serum sodium concentration of 149 mEq/L, a potentially relevant finding given the possibility of relative volume contraction or altered fluid balance, and his serum potassium measured 4.9 mEq/L, an upper-range figure that required vigilant monitoring. Additional basic metabolic tests showed a creatinine value of 2.7 mg/dL, which was consistent with his known chronic kidney disease and not felt to represent a new acute kidney injury, as he reported having struggled with declining renal function for an extended period rather than experiencing any abrupt worsening in this regard. Further pointing away from a sudden deterioration, he denied major changes in his urine output over the previous day and indicated that his nephrologist had long been aware of his compromised status, with no evidence of an acute renal insult or recent shift from his usual baseline. He did, however, exhibit signs of anemia, with a hematocrit measured at 28 %, prompting questions about potential chronicity in his reduced hematologic reserve. Frontline laboratory data further showed that his white blood cell count stood at 11,200 per cubic millimeter, slightly higher than normal and possibly reflecting an early immune response to an occult infectious or inflammatory trigger. Arterial blood sampling revealed a pH of 7.41, near the center of the normal range, indicating that acid–base status had not yet veered into overt disturbance, even though his respiratory pattern suggested the potential for developing changes if his rate continued to escalate. Simultaneously, his arterial oxygen tension was at 72 mm Hg while he was receiving a moderate level of supplemental oxygen—roughly just over one-third of the inspired mixture (FiO₂ 36 %)—which was sufficient to maintain reasonable saturation in spite of his labored breathing. His Glasgow Coma Score was calculated at 14 on the standard 15-point scale. Notably, he had a history of long-term kidney dysfunction characterized by consistently high creatinine readings, and his current value was in keeping with this chronic baseline rather than suggesting acute renal failure. Although he reported some transient episodes of fatigue and fluid retention over the years, there was no clear evidence to suggest that he had recently encountered a brand-new renal insult requiring emergent dialysis or additional renal support measures at this point. Despite his formidable fatigue, he remained strong enough to communicate, which aided the team in discerning the timeline of his symptoms, and he stated that he had never been told that his overall immune defenses were compromised in a way that would severely raise his risk for opportunistic conditions. Nevertheless, he did have some other risk factors and ongoing conditions that clinicians feared might compound the situation if his current febrile illness or presumed infection required aggressive intervention. Given his heightened respiratory rate and the possibility of progressive deterioration, he was placed under close surveillance in the immediate postoperative period after an urgent procedure that had been performed earlier the same day, rather than awaiting a future operation. At the time of admission, he was mildly sweaty, complaining of persistent chills, and describing diffuse muscle aches that intensified over the past twenty-four hours. Staff kept careful watch on his cardiac rhythm, noting that although his pulse was slightly below triple digits initially, it trended upward intermittently when he shifted in bed. He was not yet receiving vasoactive medications or intravenous antibiotics, as the final source of his symptoms remained unclear and required further diagnostic imaging and culture data for clarification. Despite the uncertainty, the presence of fever, abnormal blood studies, chronic advanced kidney impairment with a high baseline creatinine, and a moderately elevated respiratory drive collectively underscored the severity of his presentation. His older age and precarious renal function also meant he was at increased risk for fluid imbalances and electrolyte swings, both of which merited meticulous oversight prior to any definitive operative management. Should an urgent procedure become inevitable to address complications such as an intra-abdominal source of infection or another emergent condition, the team was prepared to coordinate with surgical colleagues promptly. For the moment, he remained alert enough to provide further medical history, reinforce the timeline of his symptoms, and cooperate with bedside testing, all while showing stable but potentially tenuous vital parameters that required immediate and continuous observation in the intensive care environment.

Patient Note: A 75-year-old female arrived at the emergency department describing four days of progressive respiratory discomfort that worsened considerably in the last 24 hours. She reported having felt slightly chilled on and off, yet only noted a mild elevation in her temperature when she checked it at home, which was confirmed on arrival as moderately above her usual baseline, though not strikingly high at 37.6 degrees Celsius. She indicated that her coughing, which began as an intermittent irritation, gradually intensified and was now accompanied by minimal sputum production. Though she did not appear confused or disoriented during the interview, she mentioned being more fatigued than usual, finding simple household activities taxing. She has resided independently for many years, taking care of her daily needs without ongoing assistance, and specifically noted living in her own house rather than a supervised environment. She claimed no further limitations except for occasionally reduced stamina related to a neurological event in her past, which she said caused transient weakness and difficulty with coordination several years earlier. According to her recollection, careful management and rehabilitation helped her regain much of her functionality, but she still routinely follows up with her physician to ensure there are no late complications. She also recalled a longstanding concern involving her liver that once led her to attend specialized evaluations, though she did not elaborate extensively on the details aside from stating that she has to be mindful of potential side effects when prescribed new medications. She denied significant cardiac difficulties that would require regular attention for fluid management and has experienced no episodes of fluid accumulation in her extremities or lungs that might point to a chronic heart condition; she insisted her heart rate fluctuations are typically mild. On examination, she was alert, cooperative, and oriented to time, place, and situation, with no lapse in her current mental clarity. Her breathing, however, caught the attention of the clinical team, given that her rate of inspirations was measured at 15 per minute, which was within an acceptable range but did not match the degree of subjective discomfort she reported. Her pulse was notably elevated at 105 beats per minute, though its rhythm was regular. Documentation of her systolic blood pressure revealed a value of 114 mm Hg, consistent with a mildly reduced level for her typical readings but not acutely alarming. Laboratory results obtained prior to any intervention provided further insight into her presentation. A test gauging her systemic acid-base status returned a reading of 7.32, suggesting a shift toward acidity that merited continued observation and possible additional studies to determine the cause. Her oxygenation status, measured in an arterial sample, showed a partial pressure of 74 mm Hg, which aligned with her subjective complaints of difficulty taking a full breath and feeling winded after minimal exertion. A renal function indicator remained within a reasonable range at 17 mg/dL, and she experienced no known deficits in her kidney output or filtration capacity, stating that her urine production and serum chemistry have generally stayed stable at her routine checkups. An electrolyte panel signaled that her serum sodium was on the higher end, with a measurement of 148 mEq/L, prompting the team to consider her hydration status and dietary intake. Additional labs revealed that her red blood cell concentration was at 50%, a figure that did not appear to compromise her oxygen-carrying capacity, and her serum glucose reading of 114 mg/dL appeared mildly above average but not indicative of a significant metabolic disturbance.nRadiographic imaging of her thorax displayed evidence of infection, along with a collection of fluid located around one lung field, which was consistent with the findings of dullness to percussion and altered breath sounds on physical examination. This fluid accumulation raised the possibility of complications related to her acute presentation, though she did not endorse any known chronic processes that typically result in recurrent fluid build-up in the pleural space. She recalled no abrupt changes to her usual patterns of activity besides progressive shortness of breath over the past several days, indicating that she continued performing the majority of her daily routines before feeling forced to seek medical attention for this escalating respiratory distress. She reiterated that she had no recent hospital admissions or major interventions, and her prior physician visits revolved around regular follow-up evaluations of her past neurological issue and intermittent monitoring of her liver status. Despite the significant respiratory findings, she did not exhibit confusion, speech difficulties, or notable lapses in memory during evaluation, steadily maintaining awareness of her situation. Given her advanced age and the multiple considerations posed by her past medical history, the clinical team determined that her symptoms, exam findings, and laboratory results warranted further in-hospital workup. Her stable but not entirely reassuring vital signs were taken into account before deciding on any acute therapy, ensuring that every relevant baseline measure was documented and understood prior to initiating treatment.

Patient Note: A 67-year-old male arrived at the emergency department reporting several days of worsening cough, mounting fatigue, and a high fever that he first noted upon waking the previous morning. He stated that his cough, initially nonproductive with mild throat irritation, had evolved into a deeper, more distressing pattern over the last day or so, and he began to experience chills and consistent warmth to the touch. At presentation, he was alert and engaged, conversing readily without any signs of confusion or mental cloudiness. According to him, he lives independently in a single-story residence and has not required ongoing skilled care or around-the-clock supervision. He recalls a neurological event several years ago that temporarily affected his speech and coordination, though he says he eventually recovered with rehabilitative support. He also mentions that he has required periodic evaluations for a medical condition tied to certain aspects of his metabolism, though he reports having remained stable in recent times with no major flare-ups. Nevertheless, he became concerned when his current symptoms failed to improve with usual home measures such as rest and oral hydration. On evaluation, his core temperature was measured at 38.9 degrees Celsius, reflecting a significant fever consistent with the abrupt onset of his symptoms. Physical assessment showed that he was breathing at a rate of about 17 breaths per minute and maintaining a heart rate of approximately 100 beats per minute, which he acknowledged felt faster than normal for him when he attempted mild activity. His blood pressure was recorded as 135 mm Hg on the systolic reading, aligning with a stable circulatory status for someone of his age. He displayed no outward evidence of fluid accumulation in his lower extremities or jugular venous distension, and he denied any chest pain beyond the occasional discomfort from deep coughing. When asked about his general medical history, he stated he had been followed intermittently over the years for a significant but well-controlled liver-related condition, which had not necessitated recent hospital admissions. Initial laboratory results showed a mild disturbance in his acid-base balance, with a pH documented at 7.46, though his clinical examination did not suggest any overt respiratory or metabolic compromise. He was found to have a partial pressure of oxygen of 87 mm Hg on room air, confirming that his oxygen level was somewhat lower than desired for an individual without known chronic lung issues. Additional lab testing highlighted an elevated blood urea measurement of 31 mg/dL, raising suspicion that he might be experiencing increased protein breakdown or a reduced intravascular volume status, which could complicate recovery. His serum sodium concentration was noted to be 132 mEq/L, just below normal limits, which, in conjunction with his ongoing fever and reduced oral intake, could signify evolving electrolyte fluctuations. A hematocrit value of 33% indicated a borderline low red cell volume, though he reported no significant dizziness or lightheadedness beyond what he assumed stemmed from feeling feverish. His measured glucose of 128 mg/dL was slightly above his baseline, which he attributed to decreased appetite and occasional sugary sports drinks he consumed to stay hydrated when his cough worsened. Chest auscultation revealed coarse breath sounds over the right lateral lung fields, and imaging confirmed findings of inflammation and fluid layering within the thoracic cavity, consistent with a localized infectious process and excess fluid accumulation. Despite his evident infection and the presence of fluid in the pleural space, he remained oriented throughout the conversation, recounting details about his daily activities and stressing that he has never relied on institutional living arrangements. The team acknowledged that his prior neurological history and ongoing liver-related concerns, though not actively flaring, could affect his overall resilience. With that in mind, he was prepared for further evaluation and management directed at controlling his acute condition, including monitoring of his oxygen levels, repeating relevant laboratory analyses, and ensuring any unstable parameters were addressed without delay.

He denied experiencing any acute episodes of unilateral weakness, facial droop, or slurred speech in the past, and he reported no longstanding liver problems. He described a past difficulty with kidney function, requiring follow-up with specialists, and also revealed a remotest history of a malignant growth for which he received treatment several years ago. On further questioning, he stated that his usual medications include those needed to monitor both his chronic conditions and his past oncologic management, although he did not recall any medication specifically for significantly compromised cardiac output. He claimed that he has never been told he suffered from sudden neurologic attacks or blood supply problems to his brain and had not visited any facility for such concerns. He reported no sign of abdominal issues, and he had never been diagnosed with disorders that would impair liver enzymes or clotting factors. Recent activity levels have diminished because of his respiratory discomfort, which he first attributed to a seasonal change. However, with the escalation of his breathing difficulties and fever, he became worried. Despite staying hydrated, he felt persistently thirsty, and routine checks at home indicated elevated fingerstick readings, prompting him to mention prior abnormal glucose measurements to medical providers. On arrival, his vital signs showed a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg.
